abstract.t: This document aims to document concensus on the CAPPORT architecture. DHCP, ICMP, and an HTTP API are used to provide the solution.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Problems with captive portals have been described in .
This document standardizes an architecture for implementing captive portals that provides tools for addressing most of those problems.
The architecture also attempts to enable IoT devices, in particular devices without user interfaces, to navigate a captive portal.

The architecture uses the following mechanisms:
DHCP/DHCP6 providing end-user devices with a URI in the Captive-Portal Router Advertisement option . This URI is an API that the end-user devices access for information about what is required to escape captivity.
Notifying end-user devices of captivity with ICMP/ICMP6 "unreachable" messages. This notification can work with any internet protocol, not just clear-text HTTP. This notification does not carry the portal URI, rather triggers the DHCP-provisioned portal to be accessed. This notification carries a "reason" that allows the devices to receive customized work-flows at the portal.
Receipt of the ICMP/ICMP6 messages inform an end-user device that it is captive. This permits the device to take immediate action to satisfy the portal (according to its configuration/policy). The architecture recommends the device to query the DHCP-provisioned CAPPORT URI with the specified "reason". This API returns a status and a menu for navigating the captive portal. Typically one of the menu items is a web page suitable for browsing.
The architecture attempts to provide privacy, authentication, and safety mechanisms to the extent possible.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Terminlogogy
section.t: Captive Network: A network for which communication outside of it is subject to a captive portal
Captive Portal Enforcement: The device which enforces the captive portal in the captive netowrk
Captive Portal Client: Also know as Client. A device which wants to communicate outside the captive network

section.title: DHCP
section.t: A standard for providing a portal URI is described in . The CAPPORT architecture expects this URI to access the API described in .

Although it is not clear from RFC7710 what protocol should be executed at the specified URI, it may have been assumed to be an HTML page, and hence there may be clients assuming a browser should open this URI. For backwards compatibility, it might be necessary for the server to check Agent-Id when serving the URI.

section.title: ICMP/ICMP6
section.t: A mechanism to trigger captive portal work-flows in the end-user device is proposed earlier in .

section.title: Captive Portal API
section.t: The client performs GET at the DHCP-specified URI. The response is a JSON document.

* must support a secure channel (e.g. HTTPS) * High level document describes further APIs allowing clients to make decisions * Can provide options for interactive or non-interactive clients * May want to provide a default http captive portal for clients wihch expect it * Should be able to: * Ask for quota information (remaining time/bytes/etc) * Ask whether allowed through captive portal * Provide credentials to gain access * Describe the required credentials to gain access

section.title: Client
section.t: The device attepmting to communicate outside the captive network.

* May be interactive or non-iteractive * May have different mechanisms for notifying the user of the captive portal * Needs to recognize the ICMP unreachable message, and to invoke its captive portal handling in response to it. * Needs to cache the URI for the captive portal API from the DHCP lease. * May cache credentials to respond to captive portal notifications * Interactive clients typically ask their users how to proceed through interacting with the captive portal. Interactions may be as simple as accepting a terms of agreement, or as complicated as filling out some forms. * An example interactive client is a smart phone. * Non interactive clients will likely be provisioned with credentials in order to automatically gain access. * An example non interactive client is an IoT device such as a smart thermostat. * May need to distinguish between types of clients here.

section.title: Captive Portal Enforcement
section.t: The Captive Portal Enforcement component applies captive portal policy to traffic moving between the captive network and the rest of the internet.
* Sends ICMP for disallowed clients * Allows traffic through for allowed clients * Updates policy in response to operations from the Captive Portal API.

section.title: Solution Workflow
section.t: This section describes the general workflow of solutions adhering to the architecture.

Initial connection 1) The client joins the captive network by acquiring a DHCP lease 2) The client learns the URI for the Captive Portal API from the DHCP response (rfc7710) 3) The client attemps a connection outside the captive network 4) The captive portal enforcement device drops the connective requests, and replies with an icmp unreach indicating that it is behind a captive portal, and that access is denied (I-D.wkumari-capport-icmp-unreach) *** Is this drop okay? *** 5) The client handles the icmp unreachable message by invoking its captive portal handling infrastructure 6) The captive portal handling infrastructure communicates with the Captive Portal API to gain access to outside the captive network 7) The Captive Portal API indicates to the captive portal enforcement device that the client is allowed through 8) The client's next connection attempt succeeds.

Connection about to expire 1) The client sends a packet to the outside network. 2) The captive portal device detects that the client's access is about to expire (low quota/time/etc) 3) The captive portal sends an icmp unreach to the client indicating that it needs to refresh its access. *** Will this interrupt communication somehow? *** 4) The client device handles this message by invoking its captive portal handling infrsatructure. 5) The captive portal handling infrastructure communicates with the Captive Portal API to gain access to outside the captive network 6) The Captive Portal API gives more quota to the client by indicating to the captive portal enforcement device the new, extended quota. 7) The client continues unaffected.

Connection expired. 1) The client sends a packet to the outside network. 2) The captive portal device detects that the client's access has expired. 3) The remaining workflow is that same as for the initial connection. What happens to a long-running flow here? Does it continue afterwards, or does communication need to be reestablished?

section.title: Risk of Nuisance Captive Portal
section.t:
It is possible for any user on the internet to send ICMP packets in an attempt to cause the receiving equipment to go to the captive portal. This has been considered and addressed in the following ways:
The ICMP packet does not carry the URL, making this method safer than 307-redirect methods currently in use.
The ICMP packet carries a token that would not be available, even to an on-path attacker. Although possible to guess by brute force, the impact is nuisance due to other precautions.
Even when redirected, the client securely authenticates with API servers.

section.title: User Options
section.t: The ICMP messaging informs the end-user device it is being held captive. There is no requirement that the device do something about this. Devices may permit users to disable automatic reaction to captive-portal indications. Hence, support is provided for users who wish to manually navigate the captive portal.
